newsitem.title: CANADA: GM Canada pact paves way for production, UAW deal.
newsitem.headline: GM Canada pact paves way for production, UAW deal.

text.p: General Motors Corp. plants and suppliers idled by a 20-day strike in Canada were set to creak back to life after Wednesday's expected ratification of a new labour contract with the Canadian Auto Workers union.
About 26,000 CAW workers were set to vote on the new contract at meetings in Ontario and Quebec and results were due Wednesday evening, union officials said.
Approval of the new pact also was expected to clear the way for GM to reach a quick labour agreement in the United States with the much-larger United Auto Workers union.

Some UAW sources said Wednesday that a deal could be reached in a matter of days. The U.S. talks, which affect 215,000 hourly workers, were moving quickly when the Canadian strike started on Oct. 2 and stole the spotlight from UAW President Stephen Yokich.

"I think without question they would have settled by now, but the UAW did not want to undermine the Canadian union's negotiating stance," said Harley Shaiken, a professor of labour relations at the University of California-Berkeley. "The (UAW) negotiations will move very quickly."

Sources close to the talks said they thought that GM will agree to guarantee jobs for 95 percent of its UAW work force -- nominally the same terms that rivals Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. agreed to -- but that level may exclude some U.S. parts plants now up for sale.
As in Canada, the major unresolved issues in the United States include GM's ability to shift work to outside suppliers, known as outsourcing, and the sale of parts plants.

In the Canadian settlement, GM won the right to sell parts plants in Windsor and Oshawa, Ontario, employing 3,850. The automaker also wants to sell a door hardware plant in Flint, Mich., and an interior trim plant in Livonia, Mich., that together employ 2,100 UAW members.
UAW officials said the buyer for all four of the U.S. and Canadian plants was Joseph, Littlejohn and Levy, a New York-based investment firm that owns other auto parts firms.
GM also has said it was studying options for other parts plants. It has about a dozen facilities that it considers "troubled."
The three-year Canadian pact, in addition to allowing GM to sell the Ontario parts plants, includes a pledge by the automaker to recognise limits on outsourcing.
The union, in turn, made a major concession by accepting that GM's business plan may require deviance from a pattern agreement reached in September with Chrysler.
Some of GM's Canadian workers will return to their jobs on Thursday and all of the automaker's Canadian operations will be running normally by Nov. 4, union officials said Wednesday.
"Our employees are going to get back to work and we're going to get this Canadian economy rolling," GM Canada chief negotiator Dean Munger said after the deal was reached Tuesday afternoon.
The walkout by Canadian workers idled 20,000 GM workers in the United States and Mexico and paralysed suppliers across North America.

Oshawa, Ontario-based Verspeeten Cartage Ltd., which idled about 360 of its 400 workers during the walkout, said a return to pre-strike delivery levels for its fleet of transport trucks would take up to 10 days.

"(GM is) telling us that all the operations won't be back until Nov. 4. The truck plant in Oshawa is starting tomorrow night, the car plants (in Oshawa and Ste-Therese, Quebec) will start up Nov. 4. So we should be back to normal Nov. 4," said Verspeeten's operations manager Frank Cassano.
Analysts said the strike's effect on U.S. plants could last for several more days becuse the parts pipeline from Canada may take a while to refill.
David Healy, an auto analyst with Burnham Securities Inc., said production losses due to the strike will not be fully known until all plants return to pre-strike levels.
Healy said GM's fourth-quarter net income will be reduced by at least $225 million, a quarter of the $900 million impact of a strike at two GM brake plants in Dayton, Ohio, in March.
Ronald Glantz, of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., estimated the earnings hit at $150 million to $450 million.

Economists initially said the strike at Canada's largest private employer could cost the Canadian economy at least C$1 billion ($740 million), but analysts said the brevity of the strike will minimise its impact.
